METS:xmlData.dcterms:title: Vplivi zahodnih trendov na slovensko popularno glasbo
METS:xmlData.dcterms:alternative: Western Influences on Slovenian Pop Music
METS:xmlData.dcterms:creator: Rendla, Marta
METS:xmlData.dcterms:abstract: Avtorica na podlagi literature in popularnega tiska (Tedenska tribuna, Antena) prikaže razvoj slovenske popularne glasbe v času po drugi svetovni vojni - od osvoboditve do osemdesetih let - kako in v kakšni meri so vplivali zahodni trendi na nastanek in razvoj množičnih glasbenih oblik v državi s socialističnim sistemom. Intenzivnost seznanjanja z zahodnimi glasbenimi smernicami, ki so po prvi svetovni vojni začele krojiti svetovno glasbeno prizorišče, je bila pri nas odvisna od danih družbeno političnih razmer oziroma od jugoslovanskega odpiranja proti zahodnemu svetu. V povojnem obdobju so se kot oblike slovenske popularne glasbe, ki so z zamikom ali pa skoraj sočasno sledile razvoju Zahoda, zvrstile jazzovska glasbena zvrst, pop glasba s popevkami in beat slogom, rockovska in punkovska glasba.

Based on an analysis of literature and popular magazines (Tedenska tribuna, Antena) the paper discusses the development of Slovene popular music in the period between the end of the Second World War and the 1980s, examining how, and to what degree, Western trends influenced the appearance and development of music forms in socialist Slovenia. The intensity of contacts with these musical trends that at that time started to shape the overall music scene, depended upon the current politicai circumstances and ideology in Slovenia and, as a result, the willingness of Yugoslavia to open to Western influences. The various music genres that appeared in Slovenia after the Second World War, which followed the Western trends shortly or with a longer interval, included jazz, pop music with pop songs and beat music, rock, and punk.

popularna slovenska glasba
